deliberation: The verse literally commands Ezekiel to take a brick and engrave Jerusalem on it. Within prophetic literature, such object-acts are symbolic sign-acts: the brick stands for the city itself. So while the wording is concrete, the communicative force is figurative (a miniature representing the real city).

instances.explanation: The brick functions metaphorically as Jerusalem itself; the engraved city on the brick is a symbolic model of the actual city that will soon be besieged.

deliberation: The instructions to build siege works on the engraved brick are literal acts but they function as a symbolic representation of the future Babylonian siege of Jerusalem. The language itself is straightforward military terminology used figuratively in the sign‑act.

deliberation: Two figurative elements appear: (1) the iron plate used 'as an iron wall' between the prophet and the city, symbolizing an impenetrable barrier and divine withdrawal; (2) the idiomatic expression 'set your face against it,' a conventional metaphor for determined hostility. The verse also names the whole act as a 'sign' for Israel, confirming its symbolic nature.

deliberation: The command to lie on the left side is literal within the vision, but it is a sign‑act that ‘bears the iniquity’ of Israel. The key figurative component is the metaphor of iniquity as a burden that can be carried or borne by someone’s body and time.

deliberation: God declares he will put cords on Ezekiel so he cannot turn until the days of siege are completed. The cords are literal within the vision but figuratively signify the inescapability and constraint of the coming siege and judgment.

deliberation: The verse details mixed grains and legumes baked into bread and eaten for 390 days. While the mixture and duration are symbolically significant for the siege conditions, the wording itself is straightforward instruction without a distinct lexical or phrasal metaphor, simile, or idiom.

Ezekiel’s food is to be weighed, twenty shekels per day. This literally depicts rationing in the sign‑act. It is symbolic of scarcity, but the language itself (“by weight, twenty shekels”) is descriptive and not a distinct figurative expression.

Similarly, the measured water (a sixth of a hin) portrays literal rationing within the sign‑act. Though the act symbolizes future scarcity, the phrasing is not metaphorical, idiomatic, or hyperbolic; it is precise instruction.

Ezekiel is told to bake barley cakes on human excrement before their eyes. The action is literal within the vision but functions symbolically, anticipatorily, of defiled conditions of eating in exile (explicitly explained in v.13). The core figurative element is using human excrement as a sign of ritual and social defilement.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהִיא בְּגֶלְלֵי צֵאַת הָאָדָם תְּעֻגֶנָה לְעֵינֵיהֶם

instances.explanation: Human excrement as fuel is a metaphorical sign of the uncleanness and degraded conditions under which Israel will have to eat in exile.

deliberation: God interprets the sign: Israel will eat their bread “impure among the nations.” Two elements stand out: (1) the earlier excrement imagery is now glossed as ‘impure,’ and (2) ‘bread’ functions as a synecdoche/metonymy for all food and, more broadly, for subsistence conditions in exile.

instances.hebrew_text: כָּכָה יֹאכְלוּ בְנֵי־יִשְׂרָאֵל אֶת־לַחְמָם טָמֵא בַּגּוֹיִם

posture: Explanation of the earlier shocking sign‑act
instances.explanation: Here ‘bread’ stands metonymically for Israel’s entire food supply and, more broadly, for their impure conditions of life among the nations.

deliberation: Ezekiel protests that he has never eaten carcass, torn meat, or abominable flesh. The terms used are standard Torah purity vocabulary; ‘my person was never defiled’ is cultic-legal language rather than an independent metaphorical innovation within this context. No distinct idiom or non‑literal expression stands out beyond the technical purity usage.

God grants a modification of the sign‑act: cow dung may replace human excrement. This adjusts the earlier symbolic act but does not introduce a new figurative mapping; the same defilement symbolism established in vv.12–13 simply continues with a less extreme fuel. There is no additional, distinct figure in the wording of this verse itself.

The key figurative expression is “I am going to break the staff of bread in Jerusalem.” ‘Staff of bread’ is a well‑known metaphor for bread/food as that which supports life as a staff supports a person. The subsequent mention of eating bread by weight and drinking water by measure in anxiety and horror is vivid but essentially descriptive of siege scarcity rather than a new metaphor.

instances.explanation: ‘Staff of bread’ treats food as a staff that upholds life; breaking it metaphorically depicts God withdrawing the city’s sustaining resources.

deliberation: The verse culminates in the phrase ‘they shall waste away (or melt) in their iniquity,’ portraying the people’s physical and emotional collapse with a melting/wasting metaphor. The staring at one another in shock is vivid but can be taken literally; the main figurative element is the ‘melting’ in iniquity.

instances.explanation: The verb ‘waste away/melt’ portrays the effects of iniquity as a kind of bodily and existential dissolution, turning moral guilt into a vivid image of physical decay.
